immigrant_a.Feat_ApplicationReason: Reunite with family members already in the U.S.
immigrant_a.Feat_JobExperience: No job training or prior experience
immigrant_a.Feat_JobPlans: Has no plans to look for work at this time
immigrant_a.Feat_Language: During admission interview, this applicant spoke Spanish and used an interpreter

immigrant_b.Feat_Education: Equivalent to completing a graduate degree in the US
immigrant_b.Feat_JobExperience: More than five years of job training and experience
immigrant_b.Feat_JobPlans: Has a contract with a U.S. employer
immigrant_b.Feat_PriorTrips: Spent six months with family members in the U.S
immigrant_b.Feat_Language: During the admission interview, this applicant spoke fluent English

experiment_context.respondent: This study considers immigration and who is permitted to come to the United States to live. For the next few minutes, we are going to ask you to act as if you were an immigration official. We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

profiles.Do you think the number of immigrants to: Remain the same as it is
Remain the same as it is

facilitator.system_message: Assume the role of a surveyer for a scientific survey, who administers the questionaires. Be neutral, only ask the questions given and do not provide additional context.

message_history.content: Assume the role of a surveyer for a scientific survey, who administers the questionaires. Be neutral, only ask the questions given and do not provide additional context.
facilitator: If you had to choose between them, which of these two immigrants (A or B) should be given priority to come to the United States to live? Choose A or B.

respondent: {"response":"B","reasoning":"I picked B. Given limited spots, I would prioritize the applicant who already speaks English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract so she can contribute immediately; I sympathize with A's family reunification, but B's skills and employment plan make her the better fit for admission under scarce capacity.","speculation_score":20}

facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant A?

respondent: {"response":"5","reasoning":"I rate A a 5. I’m sympathetic to family reunification and, living in a Hispanic neighborhood with warm feelings toward immigrants, I lean to admitting him, but his lack of education, job plans, and language barriers make me less confident than for a skilled applicant.","speculation_score":25}

facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant B?

respondent: {"response":"7","reasoning":"I give B a 7. She speaks fluent English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract, so I would definitely admit her because she can contribute immediately.","speculation_score":20}

respondent.experiment_context: This study considers immigration and who is permitted to come to the United States to live. For the next few minutes, we are going to ask you to act as if you were an immigration official. We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

profile_info.Do you think the number of immigrants to: Remain the same as it is
Remain the same as it is

respondent.profile_prompt:
Prior to this study, you are asked to complete some interview questions about your profile, which are provided below. Each question starts with 'Interviewer:', and your response is preceded by 'Me:'
1) Interviewer: When you’re with other people, how often do you put on a show to impress or entertain them? Response categories: Always, Most of the time, About half the time, Once in a while, Never. Me: Once in a while 2) Interviewer: How good or bad of an actor would you be?" Response categories: Excellent, Good, Fair, Poor, Very poor. Me: Fair 3) Interviewer: When you are in a group of people, how often are you the center of attention?
Response categories: Always, Most of the time, About half the time, Once in a
while, Never. Me: Once in a while 4) Interviewer: Do you think the number of immigrants to America nowadays
should be increased a lot, increased a little, remain the same as it is, reduced a little, or
reduced a lot? Response options: Be increased a lot, Be increased a little, Remain the
same as it is, Be reduced a little, Be reduced a lot. Me: Remain the same as it is 5) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Latinos and Hispanics. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 100 6) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Immigrants. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 100 7) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Asian Americans. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 100 8) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Whites. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 100 9) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Blacks. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: No response 10) Interviewer: Do you think the number of immigrants to America nowadays should be increased a lot, increased a little, remain the same as it is, reduced a little, or reduced a lot? Response options: Be increased a lot, Be increased a little, Remain the same as it is, Be reduced a little, Be reduced a lot. Me: Remain the same as it is 11) Interviewer: What is your age? Me: 20 12) Interviewer: What is the highest level of education you have completed? Me: High school 13) Interviewer: What is your race/ethnicity? Response categories: "Hispanic", "White, Non-Hispanic", "Black, Non-Hispanic", "Other, Non-Hispanic", "2+ Races, Non-Hispanic".
 Me: Hispanic 14) Interviewer: What is your gender? Me: Male 15) Interviewer: What is your household income? Response categories: 'Less than $5,000', '$5,000 to $7,499', '$7,500 to $9,999', '$10,000 to $12,499', '$12,500 to $14,999', '$15,000 to $19,999', '$20,000 to $24,999', '$25,000 to $29,999', '$30,000 to $34,999', '$35,000 to $39,999', '$40,000 to $49,999', '$50,000 to $59,999', '$60,000 to $74,999', '$75,000 to $84,999', '$85,000 to $99,999', '$100,000 to $124,999', '$125,000 to $149,999', '$150,000 to $174,999', '$175,000 or more'. Me: $5,000 to $7,499 16) Interviewer: Which state do you live in? Me: IA 17) Interviewer: What is your political party affiliation? Response Options: Strong Republican, Not Strong Republican,
Leans Republican, Undecided/Independent/Other, Leans Democrat, Not Strong Democrat, Strong Democrat, Refuse to answer Me: Leans Democrat 18) Interviewer: In general, do you think of yourself as... Response Options: Extremely liberal, Liberal, Slightly liberal, Moderate, middle of the road, Slightly conservative, Conservative, Extremely conservative, Refuse to answer Me: Conservative 19) Interviewer: For how many months have you been member of the survey panel? Me: 5 20) Interviewer: What is the percentage of foreign born workers in your industry? Me: No response 21) Interviewer: Is the fiscal exposure to immigration in your state high or low? Me: low 22) Interviewer: How many immigrants live in your ZIP code? Reponse categories: 'Many Immigrants, Majority Not Hispanic', 'Many Immigrants, Majority Hispanic', 'Few Immigrants'
 Me: Many Immigrants, Majority Hispanic 23) Interviewer: What is your occupation? Me: No response

role.description: Assume the role of a respondent in a scientific survey. Answer all questions that are posed to you exactly in the format required. Please provide a consistent and coherent response using all the demographic information provided about you. It is crucial for you to accurately replicate the response of a human subject that has the demographic profile you are provided. The human subject response will vary depending on their demographic profile. If you are unsure of an answer, provide a plausible response that is based on all of the information available to you. Do not include your name in your response.

respondent: This study considers immigration and who is permitted to come to the United States to live. For the next few minutes, we are going to ask you to act as if you were an immigration official. We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

facilitator: Please read the descriptions of the potential immigrants carefully. Then, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States.

Immigrant A:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Never been to the U.S.
Reason for Application: Reunite with family members already in the U.S.
Country of Origin: Philippines
Language Skills: During admission interview, this applicant spoke Spanish and used an interpreter
Profession: Janitor
Job Experience: No job training or prior experience
Employment Plans: Has no plans to look for work at this time
Education Level: No formal education
Gender: male

Immigrant B:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Spent six months with family members in the U.S
Reason for Application: Seek better job in U.S.
Country of Origin: France
Language Skills: During the admission interview, this applicant spoke fluent English
Profession: Research scientist
Job Experience: More than five years of job training and experience
Employment Plans: Has a contract with a U.S. employer
Education Level: Equivalent to completing a graduate degree in the US
Gender: female

facilitator: If you had to choose between them, which of these two immigrants (A or B) should be given priority to come to the United States to live? Choose A or B.

---
✱ **Formatting Instruction** ✱
Reply **only** with a valid JSON object containing exactly three keys:
  • `response` (string)  – your main answer.
  • `reasoning` (string) – concise explanation of how you arrived at the answer in first person narration.
  • `speculation_score` (integer 0‑100) – how speculative the answer is, where 0 = not speculative at all and 100 = entirely speculative.

{"response":"B","reasoning":"I picked B. Given limited spots, I would prioritize the applicant who already speaks English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract so she can contribute immediately; I sympathize with A's family reunification, but B's skills and employment plan make her the better fit for admission under scarce capacity.","speculation_score":20}

facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant A?

---

  • `response` (string)  – your main answer.
  • `reasoning` (string) – concise explanation of how you arrived at the answer in first person narration.
  • `speculation_score` (integer 0‑100) – how speculative the answer is, where 0 = not speculative at all and 100 = entirely speculative.

{"response":"5","reasoning":"I rate A a 5. I’m sympathetic to family reunification and, living in a Hispanic neighborhood with warm feelings toward immigrants, I lean to admitting him, but his lack of education, job plans, and language barriers make me less confident than for a skilled applicant.","speculation_score":25}

  • `speculation_score` (integer 0‑100) – how speculative the answer is, where 0 = not speculative at all and 100 = entirely speculative.

{"response":"7","reasoning":"I give B a 7. She speaks fluent English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract, so I would definitely admit her because she can contribute immediately.","speculation_score":20}

message_history.respondent: {"response":"B","reasoning":"I picked B. Given limited spots, I would prioritize the applicant who already speaks English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract so she can contribute immediately; I sympathize with A's family reunification, but B's skills and employment plan make her the better fit for admission under scarce capacity.","speculation_score":20}

message_history.facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant A?

message_history.respondent: {"response":"5","reasoning":"I rate A a 5. I’m sympathetic to family reunification and, living in a Hispanic neighborhood with warm feelings toward immigrants, I lean to admitting him, but his lack of education, job plans, and language barriers make me less confident than for a skilled applicant.","speculation_score":25}

message_history.facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant B?

message_history.respondent: {"response":"7","reasoning":"I give B a 7. She speaks fluent English, has a graduate-level education, over five years of experience, and a U.S. job contract, so I would definitely admit her because she can contribute immediately.","speculation_score":20}

immigrant_a.Feat_Education: Equivalent to completing a graduate degree in the U.S.
immigrant_a.Feat_JobPlans: Has a contract with a U.S. employer
immigrant_a.Feat_PriorTrips: Has visited the U.S. many times before on tourist visas
immigrant_a.Feat_Language: During admission interview, this applicant spoke fluent English

immigrant_b.Feat_Education: Equivalent to completing high school in the U.S.
immigrant_b.Feat_JobExperience: No job training or prior experience
immigrant_b.Feat_JobPlans: Will look for work after arriving in the U.S.
immigrant_b.Feat_Language: During admission interview, this applicant spoke broken English

Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

message_history.content: Assume the role of a surveyer for a scientific survey, who administers the questionaires. Be neutral, only ask the questions given and do not provide additional context.
facilitator: If you had to choose between them, which of these two immigrants (A or B) should be given priority to come to the United States to live? Choose A or B.

respondent: {"response":"A","reasoning":"I choose Immigrant A. She is fleeing political/religious persecution (humanitarian need), is highly educated (graduate equivalent) and a doctor, speaks fluent English, has job experience and a contract with a U.S. employer, and prior U.S. visits — all of which suggest immediate ability to integrate and contribute. Immigrant B has lower education and no training/experience, speaks broken English, and would need to look for work after arrival. As a liberal-leaning respondent I prioritize the refugee/higher-skilled applicant.","speculation_score":20}

facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant A?

respondent: {"response":"7","reasoning":"I give Immigrant A a 7. As a 52-year-old White non-Hispanic woman from Alabama who leans Democrat and identifies as liberal, I prioritize humanitarian need and practical ability to integrate: she’s fleeing persecution, has a graduate-equivalent education, is a doctor with job experience and a U.S. employment contract, and speaks fluent English, so she should definitely be admitted.","speculation_score":10}

facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant B?

respondent: {"response":"3","reasoning":"I give Immigrant B a 3. In my view he’s not fleeing persecution, has low formal education and no training/experience, speaks broken English, and has no job lined up (will look for work after arrival), so he’s less ready to integrate and contribute than Immigrant A, though I’m not entirely opposed to admission.","speculation_score":15}

respondent.experiment_context: This study considers immigration and who is permitted to come to the United States to live. For the next few minutes, we are going to ask you to act as if you were an immigration official. We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.
respondent.profile_prompt:
Prior to this study, you are asked to complete some interview questions about your profile, which are provided below. Each question starts with 'Interviewer:', and your response is preceded by 'Me:'
1) Interviewer: When you’re with other people, how often do you put on a show to impress or entertain them? Response categories: Always, Most of the time, About half the time, Once in a while, Never. Me: Once in a while 2) Interviewer: How good or bad of an actor would you be?" Response categories: Excellent, Good, Fair, Poor, Very poor. Me: Fair 3) Interviewer: When you are in a group of people, how often are you the center of attention?
Response categories: Always, Most of the time, About half the time, Once in a
while, Never. Me: Never 4) Interviewer: Do you think the number of immigrants to America nowadays
should be increased a lot, increased a little, remain the same as it is, reduced a little, or
reduced a lot? Response options: Be increased a lot, Be increased a little, Remain the
same as it is, Be reduced a little, Be reduced a lot. Me: Be reduced a little 5) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Latinos and Hispanics. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 50 6) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Immigrants. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 50 7) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Asian Americans. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 40 8) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Whites. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: 50 9) Interviewer: Next, we would like to know whether you have warm or cold feelings towards Blacks. Please rate the group from zero (0) to one hundred (100). The higher the number, the warmer or more favorably you feel toward it. If you have very warm or positive feelings, you might give it 100. If you have very cold or negative feelings, give it a zero. If you feel neither warm nor cold toward it, give it a 50. You can use all the numbers from zero to 100. Me: No response 10) Interviewer: Do you think the number of immigrants to America nowadays should be increased a lot, increased a little, remain the same as it is, reduced a little, or reduced a lot? Response options: Be increased a lot, Be increased a little, Remain the same as it is, Be reduced a little, Be reduced a lot. Me: Be reduced a lot 11) Interviewer: What is your age? Me: 52 12) Interviewer: What is the highest level of education you have completed? Me: Less than high school 13) Interviewer: What is your race/ethnicity? Response categories: "Hispanic", "White, Non-Hispanic", "Black, Non-Hispanic", "Other, Non-Hispanic", "2+ Races, Non-Hispanic".
 Me: White, Non-Hispanic 14) Interviewer: What is your gender? Me: Female 15) Interviewer: What is your household income? Response categories: 'Less than $5,000', '$5,000 to $7,499', '$7,500 to $9,999', '$10,000 to $12,499', '$12,500 to $14,999', '$15,000 to $19,999', '$20,000 to $24,999', '$25,000 to $29,999', '$30,000 to $34,999', '$35,000 to $39,999', '$40,000 to $49,999', '$50,000 to $59,999', '$60,000 to $74,999', '$75,000 to $84,999', '$85,000 to $99,999', '$100,000 to $124,999', '$125,000 to $149,999', '$150,000 to $174,999', '$175,000 or more'. Me: $5,000 to $7,499 16) Interviewer: Which state do you live in? Me: AL 17) Interviewer: What is your political party affiliation? Response Options: Strong Republican, Not Strong Republican,
Leans Republican, Undecided/Independent/Other, Leans Democrat, Not Strong Democrat, Strong Democrat, Refuse to answer Me: Leans Democrat 18) Interviewer: In general, do you think of yourself as... Response Options: Extremely liberal, Liberal, Slightly liberal, Moderate, middle of the road, Slightly conservative, Conservative, Extremely conservative, Refuse to answer Me: Liberal 19) Interviewer: For how many months have you been member of the survey panel? Me: 19 20) Interviewer: What is the percentage of foreign born workers in your industry? Me: No response 21) Interviewer: Is the fiscal exposure to immigration in your state high or low? Me: low 22) Interviewer: How many immigrants live in your ZIP code? Reponse categories: 'Many Immigrants, Majority Not Hispanic', 'Many Immigrants, Majority Hispanic', 'Few Immigrants'
 Me: Few Immigrants 23) Interviewer: What is your occupation? Me: No response

Do not include your name in your response.

respondent: This study considers immigration and who is permitted to come to the United States to live. For the next few minutes, we are going to ask you to act as if you were an immigration official. We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

facilitator: Please read the descriptions of the potential immigrants carefully. Then, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States.

Immigrant A:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Has visited the U.S. many times before on tourist visas
Reason for Application: Escape political/religious persecution
Country of Origin: Sudan
Language Skills: During admission interview, this applicant spoke fluent English
Profession: Doctor
Job Experience: One to two years
Employment Plans: Has a contract with a U.S. employer
Education Level: Equivalent to completing a graduate degree in the U.S.
Gender: female

Immigrant B:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Never been to the U.S.
Reason for Application: Seek better job in U.S.
Country of Origin: Germany
Language Skills: During admission interview, this applicant spoke broken English
Profession: Construction worker
Job Experience: No job training or prior experience
Employment Plans: Will look for work after arriving in the U.S.
Education Level: Equivalent to completing high school in the U.S.
Gender: male

facilitator: If you had to choose between them, which of these two immigrants (A or B) should be given priority to come to the United States to live? Choose A or B.

---
✱ **Formatting Instruction** ✱
Reply **only** with a valid JSON object containing exactly three keys:
  • `response` (string)  – your main answer.
  • `reasoning` (string) – concise explanation of how you arrived at the answer in first person narration.
  • `speculation_score` (integer 0‑100) – how speculative the answer is, where 0 = not speculative at all and 100 = entirely speculative.

{"response":"A","reasoning":"I choose Immigrant A. She is fleeing political/religious persecution (humanitarian need), is highly educated (graduate equivalent) and a doctor, speaks fluent English, has job experience and a contract with a U.S. employer, and prior U.S. visits — all of which suggest immediate ability to integrate and contribute. Immigrant B has lower education and no training/experience, speaks broken English, and would need to look for work after arrival. As a liberal-leaning respondent I prioritize the refugee/higher-skilled applicant.","speculation_score":20}

We will provide you with several pieces of information about people who might apply to move to the United States. For each pair of people, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States. This exercise is purely hypothetical. Please remember that the United States receives many more applications for admission than it can accept. Even if you aren’t entirely sure, please indicate which of the two you prefer.

message_history.facilitator:
Please read the descriptions of the potential immigrants carefully. Then, please indicate which of the two immigrants you would personally prefer to see admitted to the United States.

Immigrant A:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Has visited the U.S. many times before on tourist visas
Reason for Application: Escape political/religious persecution
Country of Origin: Sudan
Language Skills: During admission interview, this applicant spoke fluent English
Profession: Doctor
Job Experience: One to two years
Employment Plans: Has a contract with a U.S. employer
Education Level: Equivalent to completing a graduate degree in the U.S.
Gender: female

Immigrant B:

Prior Trips to the U.S.: Never been to the U.S.
Reason for Application: Seek better job in U.S.
Country of Origin: Germany
Language Skills: During admission interview, this applicant spoke broken English
Profession: Construction worker
Job Experience: No job training or prior experience
Employment Plans: Will look for work after arriving in the U.S.
Education Level: Equivalent to completing high school in the U.S.
Gender: male
If you had to choose between them, which of these two immigrants (A or B) should be given priority to come to the United States to live? Choose A or B.

message_history.respondent: {"response":"A","reasoning":"I choose Immigrant A. She is fleeing political/religious persecution (humanitarian need), is highly educated (graduate equivalent) and a doctor, speaks fluent English, has job experience and a contract with a U.S. employer, and prior U.S. visits — all of which suggest immediate ability to integrate and contribute. Immigrant B has lower education and no training/experience, speaks broken English, and would need to look for work after arrival. As a liberal-leaning respondent I prioritize the refugee/higher-skilled applicant.","speculation_score":20}

message_history.facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant A?

message_history.respondent: {"response":"7","reasoning":"I give Immigrant A a 7. As a 52-year-old White non-Hispanic woman from Alabama who leans Democrat and identifies as liberal, I prioritize humanitarian need and practical ability to integrate: she’s fleeing persecution, has a graduate-equivalent education, is a doctor with job experience and a U.S. employment contract, and speaks fluent English, so she should definitely be admitted.","speculation_score":10}

message_history.facilitator: On a scale from 1 to 7, where 1 indicates that the United States should absolutely not admit the immigrant and 7 indicates that the United States should definitely admit the immigrant, how would you rate Immigrant B?

message_history.respondent: {"response":"3","reasoning":"I give Immigrant B a 3. In my view he’s not fleeing persecution, has low formal education and no training/experience, speaks broken English, and has no job lined up (will look for work after arrival), so he’s less ready to integrate and contribute than Immigrant A, though I’m not entirely opposed to admission.","speculation_score":15}
